Dear Ms. Waidelich:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
April 15, 2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract
and ISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted
that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of ISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Repeat violations require an explanation on why the previous corrective
action plan was not successful.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4111 Job description.
An institution shall provide a job description for each staff
position that identifies rules, required qualifications, and lines of
authority.
One of thirty new hire employees did not have a job description located within their
file.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
Eleven of fourteen new hire employee files reviewed lacked an evaluation completed
by the facility within 90 days (per agency policy). Five of the eleven were noted as
being completed late, while the other six were not completed at all.
R 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan.
(3) The updated treatment plan shall include all of the following
information:
(b) Progress made toward achieving the goals established in
the previous treatment plan.
assigned to complete adoption or permanency planning for the
youth.
Three of three open youth files reviewed lacked documentation of progress made
toward goal achieve as required.
R 400.4407 Facility and premises maintenance.
(1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a clean,
comfortable, and safe condition. The facility shall be located on
land that is properly drained.
1

During the onsite inspection on April 12, 2021 bedrooms where youth no longer
reside were reviewed and had not yet been cleaned and cleared out since the
youth’s discharge. On B-side unit one youth bedroom was observed with blood
stains on the youth’s sheets, comforter and what appeared to be dried blood
smeared on the wall. It is documented this youth has self-harming behavior and is
bleeding often. Another bedroom was observed to have white towels on the floor
with a brown substance, assumed to be feces. It is documented this youth places
items in his rectum often. Walking through the building, the walls throughout the
facility were dirty and scuffed. Doors and baseboards throughout the facility were
dirty.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract/Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included
in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 All documents required for a youth should be in the youth case file, for
example immunization records. The facility had this information, but it was not
included in the youth’s file.
 All documents required for employees should be in the employee personnel
file, for example 1326 and references. The facility had this information, but it
was not included in the personnel file provided to the consultant at the time of
the review.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 The facility was not in need of consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing period.
During the period under review there have been 12 special investigations. Three
investigations are currently pending. Five investigations resulted in the facility being
2

found in full compliance. Four investigations resulted in the facility being found in
non-compliance. As a result, the facility has submitted four acceptable corrective
action plans not related to maltreatment during this licensing period. The non-
compliances included staff qualifications, health care policies and procedures, agency
policies, behavior management, and physical restraint. The agency has submitted
approved corrective action plans to address the non-compliances. During quarterly
unannounced visits and corrective action plan compliance reviews, the agency has
successfully implemented all aspects of their corrective action plans.
During the onsite visit, a walk through of the facility occurred. Medications were
locked and store securely. Meal menus were posted and ample food was present in
the facility. Staff reported they felt supported at the agency. Staff and youth both
reported feeling safe at the facility. Youth all reported their needs were being met,
specific to food, clothing and bedding. Youth also stated staff supervise them and
check on them when they are sleeping often.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on their regular license.
